Trump DOJ Arrests Don Lemon Over Coverage Of Minneapolis ICE Protests
Source: Deadline    Published: 2026-01-30 13:19:00

By Ted Johnson Political Editor UPDATED: Don Lemon was taken into custody by federal agents in Los Angeles on Thursday evening, as the journalist was in town to cover the Grammy Awards, his attorney Abbe Lowell said in a statement. ‚ÄúDon has been a journalist for 30 years, and his constitutionally protected work in Minneapolis was no different from what he has always done,‚Äù Lowell said. It was not immediately clear what charge or charges Lemon is facing. CBS News reported that he was charged with conspiracy to deprive rights. Attorney General Pam Bondi has been touting the DOJ's arrest of a number of demonstrators, and posted on X Friday, ‚ÄúAt my direction, early this morning federal agents arrested Don Lemon, Trahern Jeen Crews, Georgia Fort, and Jamael Lydell Lundy, in connection with the coordinated attack on Cities Church in St. Paul, Minnesota. More details soon.‚Äù Related Stories News BBC Reporter Broke Bias Rules By Branding Trump Fan Tommy Robinson "Sinister & Ludicrous" News Sydney Sweeney Responds To "MAGA Barbie" Claims: "I'm Not A Hateful Person" The Justice Department has been attempting to bring charges against Lemon after he covered an anti-ICE protest inside a church in the Twin Cities earlier this month capturing video and interviewing protest participants and church goers. Watch on Deadline A magistrate judge and an appeals court had earlier rejected DOJ efforts to charge Lemon, a former CNN anchor who is now an independent journalist. Lemon had said that he expected the Justice Department to continue to pursue charges even after being turned back in their initial attempts. ‚ÄúThe First Amendment exists to protect journalists whose role it is to shine light on the truth and hold those in power accountable,‚Äù Lowell said in a statement. ‚ÄúThere is no more important time for people like Don to be doing his work.‚Äù His attorney added, ‚ÄúThis unprecedented attack on the First Amendment and transparent attempt to distract attention from the many crises facing this administration will not stand. Don will fight these charges vigorously and thoroughly in court.‚Äù Fort, another independent journalist who had covered the protest, posted a video on Facebook as federal agents were at her door. She said that the agents had documentation of an indictment from a grand jury. She said, ‚ÄúI'm going to have to hop off here and surrender to agents. As a member of the press, I filmed the church protest a few weeks ago, and now I am being arrested for that.‚Äù Lemon's arrest is a long-feared escalation on the Trump administration's war on the news media, what First Amendment organizations have warned would be a chilling effect on the free press. Also this month, the Trump administration FBI executed a search warrant on the home of Hannah Natanson, a reporter for The Washington Post, seizing her computer and phones, among other things. Although Natanson was not the target of the investigation, the Post sued to seek the return of her reporting materials. Lemon live streamed the protest at Cities Church in St. Paul earlier this month, with demonstrators interrupting the services. Lemon has said that he ‚Äúhad no affiliation‚Äù to the protest organization. ‚ÄúI didn't even know they were going to this church until we followed them. We were there chronicling protests,‚Äù he said. At the time, Assistant Attorney General Harmeet Dhillon, head of the Justice Department Civil Rights Division, wrote a message to Lemon on X that the First Amendment does ‚Äúnot protect your pseudo journalism of disrupting a prayer service. You are on notice!‚Äù Donald Trump also attacked Lemon, reposting a message on Truth Social that called for the independent journalist to be jailed. During the live stream inside the church, Lemon told viewers, ‚ÄúI'm not going to get in the middle of it, because I'm not here as an activist. I'm here as a journalist.‚Äù CNN reported that Lemon is expected to make a court appearance on Friday. Patrick Schlitz, the chief judge of U.S. District Court in Minneapolis, wrote in a letter earlier this month that ‚Äúthere is no evidence that those two engaged in any criminal behavior or conspired to do so.‚Äù CNN out out a statement calling Lemon's arrest ‚Äúunacceptable.‚Äù ‚ÄúThe FBI's arrest of our former CNN colleague Don Lemon raises profoundly concerning questions about press freedom and the First Amendment,‚Äù the network said. pic.twitter.com/Yy9IOZRpJU The Committee to Protect Journalists' CEO Jodie Ginsberg said in a statement that the arrests were ‚Äúan egregious attack on the First Amendment and on journalists' ability to do their work. As an international organization, we know that the treatment of journalists is a leading indicator of the condition of a country's democracy. These arrests are just the latest in a string of egregious and escalating threats to the press in the United States ‚Äî and an attack on people's right to know.‚Äù Gabe Rottman, vice president of policy for the Reporters Committee for the Freedom of the Press, said in a statement, ‚ÄúIt's obviously concerning any time journalists are arrested in connection with their reporting. To our knowledge, it's unprecedented for the Justice Department to deploy the federal laws it has previously cited in this case against journalistic activity.‚Äù He noted that in the limited number of cases brought against a journalist documented a protest on private property, they have been trespass cases at the state level. Even then, the charges are ‚Äúalmost always‚Äù dropped, he said, and those that go to trial typically see journalists prevail. House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries condemned the arrest. He posted on X, ‚ÄúDon Lemon is an accomplished journalist whose urgent work is protected by the First Amendment. There is zero basis to arrest him and he should be freed immediately. The Trump Justice Department is illegitimate and these extremists will all be held accountable for their crimes against the Constitution.‚Äù Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-MA) said, ‚ÄúJournalism is not a crime. The Justice Department should investigate the federal agents who killed U.S. citizens in broad daylight, not arrest reporters like Don Lemon. He should be released. It's a spine-chilling assault on press freedom and threatens the public's right to know.‚Äù Get our Breaking News Alerts and Keep your inbox happy. Comments On Deadline Hollywood are monitored. So don't go off topic, don't impersonate anyone, and don't get your facts wrong. Comment Name Email Website Œî He was fired from CNN for a reason. He interrupted a church service for a reason. He serves himself only, and will stop at nothing to promote himself. Yes, sounds exactly like the president He should be referred to as the Disgraced Don Lemon. Are we surprised that the first journalist this racist, authoritarian administration arrested was black? The insanity of what is happening in America today reminds me of a line from a movie , ‚Äú and cancel Christmas!‚Äù Seems to me the impotent one is having one tantrum after another and will continue to do so until the regime is defeated This is such a lame case..can pop it with a dull pin. These hoodlums are now arresting journalists. Step up GOP..or your party will never be elected again. ‚ÄòThe Moment' Filmmaker Introduces ‚ÄúFabulous‚Äù Kylie Jenner in Acting Debut at Film's L.A. Premiere
Source: The Hollywood Reporter    Published: 2026-01-30 10:15:16

Subscribe for full access to The Hollywood Reporter Subscribe for full access to The Hollywood Reporter The audience inside Beverly Hills' Fine Arts Theatre included Chappell Roan, Joachim Trier, Sean Baker, Simon Rex, Meg Stalter, Troye Sivan, Demi Lovato, Gabbriette, Eli Roth and rocker Matt Healy. By Chris Gardner Brat summer hit the big screen in winter in Beverly Hills on Thursday. A24 hosted the L.A. premiere of Aidan Zamiri's satirical mockumentary The Moment starring pop superstar Charli xcx ‚Äî fresh from the film's Sundance world premiere last week and a red carpet outing last night at Wuthering Heights premiere (for which she did the music) ‚Äî at Fine Arts Theatre. It seemed like all the city's cool kids were there with Moment merch (like brat-branded credit cards) and vape pens in hand. In his brief introduction before the film, Zamiri noted how the location helped juice the festivities. ‚ÄúWe love this film so much,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe love Los Angeles, and fortunately there are a lot of movie stars that live in Los Angeles and a lot of them are in our film, which is great. So, I great to bring them out and show them to you.‚Äù Related Video Related Stories Movies Charli xcx Officially Kicks Off Her Acting Era at Sundance With 'The Moment': "I Want 'Brat' to Stop and Pivot" Movies 'I Want Your Sex' Review: Gregg Araki Is Back in Vintage Form, Throwing a Deliciously Paired Olivia Wilde and Cooper Hoffman Into Sub/Dom Jeopardy He welcomed stars Hailey Benton Gates, Kate Berlant, Trew Mullen, Tish Weinstock and Richard Perez to the stage along with his co-writer Bertie Brandes and producer David Hinojosa. He saved a special mention for Kylie Jenner, who makes her acting debut in the film, by calling her ‚Äúfabulous.‚Äù He then welcomed out Charli xcx by saying she ‚Äúwas born to play‚Äù her role in The Moment, which she also produced. Zamiri noted they had a blast making the film across 26 production days. ‚ÄúI love this cast so much, I love this crew so much. I'm so grateful you guys get to see it here.‚Äù Zamiri then turned his attention to Charli by saying, ‚ÄúBrat summer, forever?‚Äù Her answer? ‚ÄúMaybe!‚Äù The L.A. location also boosted the star power in the theater. Those seated for the local premiere included stars Chappell Roan, Charli's Sweat Tour mate Troye Sivan, Demi Lovato, Gabbriette, Matt Healy, Conan Gray, Tove Lo, Scout Willis, Avan Jogia, Meg Stalter, Simon Rex and Terrence O'Connor as well as filmmakers like Sean Baker, Sentimental Value's Joachim Trier and Eli Roth. After the showing, the crowd high-tailed it over to Genghis Cohen on Fairfax Avenue for a packed after party. The Moment follows Charli as she navigates the complexities of fame and industry pressure while preparing for her arena tour debut and juggling the demands of a new tour documentary and its unpredictable director, played by Alexander Skarsgard. ‚ÄúIt felt very vulnerable because I tapped into the most extreme parts of my personality that sometimes I feel the need to hide and diminish,‚Äù Charli recently told The Hollywood Reporter's David Canfield. ‚ÄúBeing an artist is a really volatile thing. One minute you can be on top of the world and think you are the best and the most important person in the room with the best ideas ‚Äî a generational artist ‚Äî and then the next minute you can feel like a piece of shit on someone's shoe. I really feel that in my journey as an artist. To actualize that was hard because I don't like feeling, especially, the latter version of that. It's scary to admit you feel like that.‚Äù At A24's The Moment premiere in LA, director Aidan Zamiri introduces ‚Äúthe fabulous‚Äù Kylie Jenner in her first acting role and the star of the show Charli XCX. Crowd included Chappell Toan, Joachim Trier, Sean Baker, Simon Rex, Meg Stalter, Terrence O'Connor, Troye Sivan, Demi‚Ä¶ pic.twitter.com/jTgBWwvnqi Sign up for THR news straight to your inbox every day Send us a tip using our anonymous form.

Hilary Duff Teases ‚ÄòWorld Tour Loading‚Ä¶' During Los Angeles Tour Stop
Source: Billboard    Published: 2026-01-30 09:07:19

The pop star announced her upcoming world tour at the final stop of her 'Small Rooms, Big Nerves' four-date trek. By Lyndsey Havens Hilary Duff is going on a world tour ‚Äî and for her longtime fans, the news really is what dreams are made of. Duff announced her long-awaited return to music last year. The pop icon signed with Atlantic Records in September and soon after shared news of her upcoming album, luck‚Ä¶ or something, out Feb. 20. She has released two singles so far, ‚ÄúMature‚Äù and ‚ÄúRoommates.‚Äù By the start of 2026, it was clear she was more than ready to dive back in and continue building on momentum. In January, Duff embarked on a four-city mini tour including London, Toronto, Brooklyn and Los Angeles. And for her hometown finale, she made sure to save a special surprise. Related Olivia Dean Beats Harry Styles to ARIA Chart Crown Friday Music Guide: New Music From Noah Kahan, Labrinth, Cannons & More HARDY, Morgan Wallen, Tim McGraw & Eric Church Join Forces for 'McArthur': Stream It Now Explore Hilary Duff See latest videos, charts and news See latest videos, charts and news Halfway through her set ‚Äî which featured beloved hits including ‚ÄúWhy Not,‚Äù ‚ÄúCome Clean‚Äù and ‚ÄúWhat Dreams Are Made Of‚Äù ‚Äî Duff invited three lucky fans on stage to dance with her. And after delivering spot-on choreography, she had a thank you gift waiting for each one of them. With their backs turned to the packed venue, Duff gave each fan a black t-shirt and told them not to turn around until her signal. Once they were all ready, the three fans spun to face the audience and revealed major news, with three words spread out across each shirt: ‚ÄúWorld Tour Loading‚Ä¶‚Äù As the crowd erupted in celebratory cheers and applause, Duff couldn't help but beam as she took it all in. ‚ÄúIt's a trip,‚Äù she later said. ‚ÄúI can't believe I'm here 18 years later.‚Äù Duff has charted seven songs on the Billboard Hot 100 and all five of her albums have debuted within the Billboard 200's top 5. Metamorphosis (2003) and Most Wanted (2005) both hit No. 1. Get weekly rundowns straight to your inbox A daily briefing on what matters in the music industry Send us a tip using our anonymous form. ‚ÄòMelania' Doc Premieres in D.C. as Director Brett Ratner Says $75 Million Price Tag ‚ÄúWasn't About Corruption‚Äù
Source: The Hollywood Reporter    Published: 2026-01-30 06:23:08

Subscribe for full access to The Hollywood Reporter Subscribe for full access to The Hollywood Reporter The Amazon MGM Studios film, which follows the First Lady in the days leading up to Trump's second inauguration, debuted with support from the president and much of his cabinet. By Carita Rizzo At the Kennedy Center premiere for Melania, the Amazon MGM Studios documentary about First Lady Melania Trump, guests heaped overly effusive praise (‚ÄúBrilliant‚Äù) on the subject of the film during the red carpet portion of the evening. ‚ÄúUnprecedented‚Äù was another word that came up specifically to describe the doc ‚Äî which reportedly was bought for $40 million and given a marketing budget of $35 million ‚Äî at Thursday's gala screening. ‚ÄúI've been to a number of performances at the Kennedy Center, and I've never seen the whole center branded,‚Äù noted one red carpet reporter. Indeed, the Kennedy Center (or the Trump-Kennedy Center, as it was referred to on the invite) had the First Lady's name printed across windows and walls, along with glowing letters across the steps and repeated everywhere. But perhaps the biggest surprise of all was the 34-minutes President Donald Trump and the First Lady dedicated to answering questions on the black carpet, from both mainstream and right-wing media outlets. ‚ÄúNice to see you,‚Äù the president greeted reporters on the press line before announcing, ‚ÄúTonight is about the First Lady.‚Äù Related Video Related Stories Music Trump Administration Claps Back at Bruce Springsteen Over "Irrelevant" Anti-ICE Protest Song Music Hopping Mad Over Bad Bunny as Super Bowl LX Performer? I Can Get You Good Odds He Wears a Maxi Dress Asked about the influence his wife wields on him, the president said, ‚ÄúShe's somebody that I count on. I speak to a lot of people. I listen to some and I don't listen to others, but she's very influential.‚Äù In terms of the film's impact on those who were about to see the film, the First Lady told reporters she hoped the film would be inspirational, especially to other women. ‚ÄúEverybody will connect on a certain level,‚Äù she told reporters. ‚ÄúTeenagers can go to see it, young women can go to see it, and be inspired that they could have a family and business, as well.‚Äù Much of the focus amongst the press was on the eye-opening deal Amazon struck with Melania Trump and her newly launched production company Muse Films. President Trump told reporters he ‚Äúwasn't involved,‚Äù while the First Lady said the producers had approached several distributors and ‚ÄúAmazon was the best because they agreed to do theaters all around the world.‚Äù The film's director Brett Ratner ‚Äî directing his first project since being accused of sexual misconduct and harassment at the height of the #MeToo movement ‚Äî received far more pointed questions about whether he felt like he was part of an act of corporate corruption. ‚ÄúThat's ridiculous, but it's OK, I'll answer. I can tell you right now, if we were audited and they said, ‚ÄòHow much was spent on this movie?', this movie is one of the most expensive movies ‚Äî documentaries ‚Äî in the genre ever made,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt wasn't about getting rich. I mean, I think the Trumps are wealthy and successful enough. This is about giving me the ability to hire the best crew in the world, to not only score the film with the best composer‚Ä¶ I mean, when you see the movie, you'll go, ‚ÄòOh, we see where the money went now.' This wasn't about corruption. Melania only cared about one thing, making a great movie for audiences.‚Äù For Ratner, the project came as a surprise. ‚ÄúI didn't plan it,‚Äù he told The Hollywood Reporter. ‚ÄúIt wasn't something I was pitching. The First Lady and [producer] Marc Beckman asked me to come and consider this and I was so moved by how forthright Melania was and how thoughtful she was. She said, ‚ÄòBrett, I want you to do this.' I said, ‚ÄòBut there's great documentary filmmakers.' She's like, ‚ÄòYeah, but I want it to be for the big screen. I want it to be a movie that audiences around the world can really enjoy.' So, I said, ‚ÄòOK, well then I'm right for the job.'‚Äù ‚ÄúIf it was just a talking-heads documentary, there's many more great filmmakers that I can suggest to them for, but if you're going to do a movie for the big screen, for audiences around the world ‚Äî make it something that's entertaining as well as informative and hopefully historical, I'm the guy,‚Äù he added. In terms of how he would define success for the project, Ratner told THR, ‚ÄúTo me, it's already a success, just the fact that Amazon has agreed to distribute this theatrically. It's a different world today. When I was a kid, all I cared about was box office. ‚ÄòHow much money is this movie going to make?' And now it's like I've already succeeded. I've grown up a little bit.‚Äù Ratner wasn't the only guest defending the unprecedented price Amazon paid for the doc that opens in 1,500 theaters worldwide on Friday (so far to rather modest ticket sales). South Africa won't be on the list of countries as the film was abruptly pulled from the schedule on Thursday. ‚ÄúAmazon is a business and they're in the business to make money, and I think they will make money on this film,‚Äù said Speaker of the House Mike Johnson. ‚ÄúIt also has an inestimable value in my view, for its cultural impact. I mean, to have a documentary of a First Lady, a behind-the-scenes portrayal, I think there's great value to that and I think it transcends dollar figures. I think Amazon's done a good thing to the culture.‚Äù Johnson, attending with his wife Kelly Lary, hoped viewers would glean what the two of them know from their personal relationship with the Trumps. ‚ÄúShe's one of the most gracious people we know,‚Äù he said of the First Lady. ‚ÄúShe's very dignified and poised. She gets attacked all the time politically, but she takes it in stride and she's, I think, a great model for other women and a great representative for America. So, this will be a great film.‚Äù Asked by THR if the timing of the premiere gave him pause ‚Äî following ICE's shooting of protestor Alex Pretti in Minneapolis and the nationwide outrage that has followed ‚Äî Johnson brushed it off. ‚ÄúNo. This was pre-planned and she can't account for weather events and madness in Congress. She's doing her thing, so we applaud it. We're here to support it and we're excited to be here,‚Äù he said. Johnson was not the only member of the Trump administration to attend the premiere, with other guests including attendance were Pete Hegseth, Lee Zeldin and Robert F. Kennedy Jr. ‚ÄúShe's been portrayed as this one-dimensional character, but that's not who she is,‚Äù Kennedy told THR. ‚ÄúShe's been very kind to me and [wife] Cheryl [Hines] since we moved to Washington. Within the administration, she's been one of the primary motivators and drivers for my agenda for children's health, for better food. I've worked with her a lot on foster care, which is her passion, and I'm excited to learn more about her.‚Äù Kennedy also defended the recent renaming of the building dedicated to his uncle President John F. Kennedy. ‚ÄúThis center was launched after my uncle's death because of his commitment to the arts, to making America a cultural center. President Trump has that same ambition. He's spending a lot of time thinking about it,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI have bigger fish to fry. If I can save one kid, it's better than the name of a building.‚Äù And though a Saturday screening of the documentary at the White House drew criticism, the president did not seem bothered by the events of the past month. Asked how he believed the month of January would affect his legacy, he said, ‚ÄúI think that the legacy is very strong right now. The safest country we've had, the strongest military, doing better than we've ever done before. I think it's going to be a great legacy.‚Äù Sign up for THR news straight to your inbox every day Send us a tip using our anonymous form.

Ariana Grande trolls Vogue for shocking Photoshop fail: ‚ÄòHoly s‚Äìt!'
Source: Page Six    Published: 2026-01-30 03:07:00

Ariana Grande poked fun at a Photoshop fail in cheeky new social media comments. Fan instagram account @ourpinkwitchh shared a pair of Vogue Japan snapshots of the ‚ÄúWicked‚Äù star in a cream-colored floral print Dior mini skirt and top, daintily raising her left hand ‚Äî which, in a closeup crop, seemingly had the faint outline of a sixth finger. The hitmaker wore a sheer white glove, and several of her hand tattoos were visible in the shot. The fan account questioned, ‚Äúwho's responsible for giving ariana 6 fingers‚Ä¶. üò≠‚Äù to which Grande replied in the comments thread, ‚Äúholy s‚Äìt.‚Äù She hilariously added in a subsequent comment, ‚Äúoh my goodness how exciting! i've been saying i need some extra appendages so that i can start an album ! thankful for this.‚Äù Fans were quick to respond to Grande's clever comments, with one joking, ‚Äúi knew you were hiding something,‚Äù and another chiming in, ‚ÄúAriana AI Grande.‚Äù ‚ÄúThis is my wallpaper and I just noticed üò≠‚Äù quipped a third, while a fourth confessed, ‚ÄúI DIDNT EVEN NOTICE.‚Äù A rep for Vogue did not immediately return Page Six's request for comment. It's unclear where the original image came from ‚Äî an almost identical photo from Vogue Japan's stunning new spread featuring the singer did not have the hint of a second pinkie. Grande, 32, channeled retro vibes in several dresses in the high fashion collection of photos. The multi-hypenate talent ‚Äî who collected a rising star award at the Palm Springs Film Festival earlier this month ‚Äî previously joked about how she's enhanced her youthful appearance in the past. ‚ÄúYou don't know how much it means to me,‚Äù she said after Jennifer Coolidge summoned her to the stage, according to People. ‚ÄúI've been performing since I was a child, so I never thought at the age of 31 I would be hearing the words ‚Äòrising star' again, so I wanted to start by thanking my two friends: Botox and Juvederm.‚Äù Grande isn't the only celebrity to be caught up in an apparent photoshop gaffe. In August, fans called out Kris Jenner for an apparent sixth toe in an Instagram photo ‚Äî and daughters Kim Kardashian and Kylie Jenner were previously called out for also having six toes in a 2019 ad for their fragrance collab. Celebs including Princess of Wales Kate Middleton, ‚ÄúReal Housewives of New York City‚Äù alum Ramona Singer, reality star Khlo√© Kardashian, and ‚ÄúRHONJ‚Äù personality Teresa Giudice have also been accused of photoshop missteps in recent years.

Singer on Wiz Khalifa & Charlie Puth's ‚ÄòFurious 7' Smash ‚ÄòSee You Again' Sues Over Royalties
Source: Billboard    Published: 2026-01-30 02:52:53

Jake Broido claims Warner Music Group has "obfuscated and obstructed" his attempts to collect proper payment for the chart-topper. By Rachel Scharf A backing vocalist on Wiz Khalifa and Charlie Puth's chart-topping Furious 7 soundtrack hit ‚ÄúSee You Again‚Äù is suing Warner Music Group (WMG) and NBCUniversal, alleging he was ‚Äúcheated out of royalty payments and downstream compensation‚Äù for years. Jake Broido claims in a Thursday (Jan. 29) federal court lawsuit that he provided the so-called gang vocals on ‚ÄúSee You Again,‚Äù which scored Paul Walker's famous final scene in 2015's Furious 7 and reigned atop the Billboard Hot 100 for 12 weeks. But he alleges WMG and NBCUniversal misclassified his contributions on the song's registration paperwork, ultimately depriving him of royalties and licensing fees. ‚ÄúIt is, of course, not surprising that Broido's efforts to get paid have been, for a decade, obfuscated and obstructed by Warner,‚Äù reads the complaint. ‚ÄúThat is the long history of the music industry; to make executives rich at the expense of artists.‚Äù Broido alleges he was working as an administrative staffer at WMG in early 2015 when Puth approached him asking if he could sing gang vocals, a recording technique where voices are layered to sound like crowd noise. Broido, who had been studying gang vocals for years, says he happily went into the studio with Puth and sang what would ultimately become part of ‚ÄúSee You Again.‚Äù Session vocalists like Broido are supposed to collect royalties through the AFM & SAG-AFTRA Intellectual Property Rights Distribution Fund. But Broido's name didn't make it onto the ‚ÄúSee You Again‚Äù AFM Fund registration paperwork; instead, the files merely listed ‚Äúthree A&R staffers‚Äù as background singers. Broido alleges that WMG, whose subsidiary Atlantic Records released the Furious 7 soundtrack, deliberately doctored the AFM Fund paperwork because it hadn't secured a critical work-for-hire agreement from him. According to the lawsuit, WMG wanted to hide this ‚Äúembarrassing failure‚Äù from its studio partners at NBCUniversal. The result, alleges Broido, is that he wasn't paid crucial royalties that should have been distributed to him by the AFM Fund. He says WMG also misclassified ‚ÄúSee You Again‚Äù as ‚Äúnon-theatrical‚Äù on the registration paperwork, which deprived him of the chance to participate in lucrative licensing negotiations. ‚ÄúWarner Music made misleading statements, partial royalty payments and assurances to Broido that it was pursuing an investigation, including that it would ‚Äòlook into this' and that it would ‚Äòfollow up,' only for Warner Music to ultimately ‚Äòghost' Broido,‚Äù reads the complaint. ‚ÄúIn reality, Warner Music's assurances were merely a scheme to conceal facts from Broido in an attempt to ‚Äòwait out the clock.'‚Äù Broido is now suing WMG and NBCUniversal for breach of contract, fraud and conspiracy. The lawsuit also levels breach of fiduciary duty claims against the AFM Fund, alleging it was ‚Äúasleep at the switch‚Äù and made ‚Äúabsurd and negligent decisions that allowed Warner Music and NBCUniversal to cheat Broido.‚Äù The background singer is seeking unspecified financial damages through the litigation, as well as a declaration that he is a co-owner of the ‚ÄúSee You Again‚Äù copyrights. Reps for WMG, NBCUniversal and the AFM Fund did not immediately return requests for comment on Thursday. Khalifa and Puth are not facing any legal claims in the case. Ahead of High-Profile Negotiations, Writers Guild West's Own Staff Union Authorizes Strike
Source: The Hollywood Reporter    Published: 2026-01-30 02:43:32

Subscribe for full access to The Hollywood Reporter Subscribe for full access to The Hollywood Reporter Eighty-two percent of unionized staffers voted to empower leaders to call a work stoppage, just months before the labor group is set to face the likes of Netflix and Paramount. By Katie Kilkenny Labor & Media Reporter The Writers Guild of America West could soon have another strike on their hands, but not one involving Hollywood's studios or streamers. Rather, the labor group's own staff union ‚Äî the union within the union, as it were ‚Äî on Thursday authorized a strike as they claim that negotiations over their first contract have stalled as management has engaged in bad-faith bargaining. Eighty-two percent of the 100 staffers that participated voted to authorize a strike, the Writers Guild Staff Union announced on Instagram on Thursday. Related Stories Business Production Workers at Big D.C. Concert Venues Vote to Unionize (Exclusive) Movies Writers Guild Awards Nominations: 'If I Had Legs I'd Kick You,' 'Weapons,' 'Bugonia,' 'Frankenstein' Among Nominees ‚ÄúIf management won't bargain in good faith with us at the table, we will see them on the picket line,‚Äù the post stated. Related Video A strike authorization does not guarantee a strike, but it does allow union leaders to call one if they deem it necessary. In a statement, the WGA West refuted allegations that management had engaged in bad-faith bargaining and said it had offered ‚Äúcomprehensive proposals with numerous union protections and improvements to compensation and benefits.‚Äù The union added, ‚ÄúPublic claims suggesting otherwise are inaccurate, and allegations of unfair labor practices are without merit. WGAW respects the staff's right to engage in collective activity, and hopes to reach a first contract agreement with the staff union soon.‚Äù The WGSU says that it has been negotiating its first contract with the union since September 2025 and is still fighting for ‚Äúbasic protections‚Äù like grievance processes, AI protections and raises for union members, according to a public flier seen by THR. ‚ÄúAt this point in negotiations, we should be in alignment on these issues. Yet for nearly five months, WGAW management has dismissed our staff's needs and engaged in bad faith surface bargaining with no intent to reach a fair contract,‚Äù the flier stated. The group added that management is attempting to ‚Äúkeep near-total control over our wages and working conditions‚Äù and that staffers ‚Äúwill not stand by and let this happen.‚Äù The timing is hardly fortuitous for the union. The WGA's east and west coast branches are just a few months out from entering the first negotiations with Hollywood studios and streamers since their 148-day strike in 2023. The union is expected to start talks on March 16, and a few months prior would typically be the time for the labor group to cement priorities and strategize, not to face their own internal labor battles. Indeed, a group of self-described WGA captains ‚Äî volunteer members that communicate union messaging to rank-and-file peers ‚Äî commented on WGSU's Instagram post expressing their solidarity. ‚ÄúWe've got your back. Always,‚Äù it stated. The WGA relied heavily on its captain system during its negotiations in 2023. The WGSU is affiliated with the Pacific Northwest Staff Union. The union was voluntarily recognized by management after a card count showed majority support for the effort in April 2025. Cardi B to Perform at Michael Rubin's Fanatics Super Bowl Party in San Francisco
Source: Billboard    Published: 2026-01-30 00:06:49

Five additional artists have been confirmed as surprise performers as well. By Michael Saponara While Cardi B will likely be at San Francisco's Super Bowl LX to cheer on her boo Stefon Diggs and his Patriots teammates, the Grammy-winning rapper is also making time for some work in the Bay Area. Fanatics announced Thursday (Jan. 29) that Cardi is slated to perform at Michael Rubin's Fanatics Super Bowl Party in San Francisco on Feb. 7. Five surprise artists are also booked to perform throughout the afternoon. Fittingly enough, Cardi also performed at the Fanatics Super Bowl Party in Atlanta in 2019, which saw Patriots owner Robert Kraft join her onstage. That year saw the Patriots defeat the Los Angeles Rams at Super Bowl LIII, so it's safe to say Cardi is hoping that history repeats itself, with Diggs and the Pats lifting the Lombardi Trophy. Michael Rubin's parties are always star-studded, and San Francisco should be no different next month. In the past, celebrities like Jay-Z, Kim Kardashian, Leonardo DiCaprio, Tom Brady, Kevin Hart, Kendall Jenner, Drake, Ben Affleck, Jennifer Lopez, Justin Bieber, Emily Ratajkowski, Kevin Durant, James Harden, Usher, Aaron Judge and Jack Harlow have been in attendance. Super Bowl LX will be a rematch of 2015, with the New England Patriots facing off against the Seattle Seahawks on Feb. 8. Cardi B has been cheering on Diggs, who's a star wide receiver for the Pats, every step of the way this NFL Playoffs. She even joined the celebration with the Patriots on the field in Denver following the team's AFC Championship victory over the Broncos. Cardi's Fanatics performance could double as tour prep, as she's slated to kick off her Little Miss Drama Tour just a few days later on Feb. 11 in Palm Desert, California, at Acrisure Arena. ‚ÄòIf I Go Will They Miss Me' Review: Walter Thompson-Hern√°ndez Delivers an Ambitious Portrait of Black Angelino Life
Source: IndieWire    Published: 2026-01-30 00:00:00

By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy. We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply. Formally ambitious and narratively elliptical, ‚ÄúIf I Go Will They Miss Me‚Äù uses a strained father-son relationship as a lens to survey, and elevate, Black Angelino life. Expanding upon his 2022 Sundance Short Film Jury Award-winning short by the same name, writer-director Walter Thompson-Hern√°ndez adopts a painter's eye towards the local Watts community. He affords faces with warm close-ups and captures individuals and groups alike in static celebratory portraits. He treats the Nickerson Gardens housing projects, the film's primary setting, like a safe haven, a place where expressions of love and conflict, murmurs of gossip and bullshit, are allowed to roam free. Thompson-Hern√°ndez acknowledges that while Watts might be a small community, a relative sliver of greater Los Angeles, imagination flourishes in the most circumscribed places. Related Stories Sundance Will Rebuild in Boulder. What Does That Look Like? ‚ÄòThe Weight' Review: Ethan Hawke Smuggles Stolen Gold in a ‚ÄòSorcerer' Homage That Drags Through the Muck Case in point: drawing and crafts are creative outlets for Lil Ant (Bodhi Dell), a sensitive twelve-year old whose interest in Greek mythology intersect with the return of his father, Big Ant (J. Alphonse Nicholson), from a stint in prison. Upon his homecoming, Lil Ant compares his father to Odysseus arriving home after years at war; later, he likens him to Poseidon, and subsequently himself to the God's trusty winged horse Pegasus. Unnerved by his son's reverence, Big Ant keeps his distance from the boy and subtly pressures him to toughen up and abandon his artistic pursuits. Popular on IndieWire While trauma and toxic masculinity linger like specters in the background of ‚ÄúIf I Go,‚Äù Thompson-Hern√°ndez permits them to merely contextualize rather than overwhelm the drama. Case in point: Big Ant's concern about his son's interest in art doesn't stem from his discomfort with its feminine implications, or that it might make him a potential target away from home. Instead, it connects with his fear that the two are more alike than he initially believed. Big Ant was also a creative adolescent until a peer-pressured assault forced him into the criminal justice system; he sees his son's passion as a harbinger of doom that will force him down a similarly harsh path. His fears intensify when he discovers that they both see the same hallucinatory vision of the neighborhood kids acting like planes, complete with outstretched arms as wings, awaiting taking off on makeshift runways. Born and raised in Huntington Park, Thompson-Hern√°ndez grew up beneath the LAX flight path and the roar of planes departing from and arriving at the airport dominated his soundscape. Subsequently, the filmmaker became enamored with airplanes and transferred that same fascination onto Lil Ant, who eyes the planes overhead with palpable yearning and, at one point, shoplifts a toy plane from a store. The dreamlike image of kids-as-planes stresses the various ‚Äúflights‚Äù that permeate ‚ÄúIf I Go‚Äù: the emotional journey of adolescence, the physical departures of adults, and people's imagined escapes for themselves far into the future. Informed and influenced by the works of Black filmmakers like Charles Burnett, Kahlil Joseph, Barry Jenkins, and Spike Lee, as well as visual artists like Jacob Lawrence and Kerry James Marshall, Thompson-Hern√°ndez brings considerable rigor to his sophomore feature. His frame exhibits a restrained beauty that honors and uplifts, rather than condescends to, its environment; in other words, he respects his audience. Thompson-Hern√°ndez's background as a feature writer for the New York Times has also supplied him with a keen ear for the spoken phrase, expressed in the film's rich and believable dialogue, as well as a facility with performers of all backgrounds. Everyone from seasoned actors like Nicholson and Danielle Brooks, who plays matriarch Lozita, to the various non-professionals that populate the frame evince a palpable comfort with being on screen, which allows them to fully inhabit their respective characters. A strong foundation of stylized realism affords ‚ÄúIf I Go‚Äù to integrate the fantastic without rendering it incoherent, illustrating a quiet confidence on behalf of its cast and crew. Yet, the clunky meanings behind such potently surreal imagery points to the noble faults in ‚ÄúIf I Go.‚Äù The overly obvious aviation motif, for example, might have had more room to breathe if it wasn't competing with the Grecian myths that Lil Ant uses to explain his family's dynamic. As much as Thompson-Hern√°ndez strives to dovetail the two metaphors into a cohesive thematic framework, they feel stubbornly separated from each other, especially as ‚ÄúIf I Go‚Äù develops. While ‚ÄúIf I Go‚Äù deserves praise for eschewing traditional three-act structure and using lyrical vignettes as a lodestar instead of an engineered plot, its central parental relationship remains frustratingly schematic, even at its most heartfelt. There are no real surprises that occur between Big and Lil Ant, our viewpoint into the film's world, or even between Big Ant and Lozita, whose relationship feels real but too familiar. Characters keep secrets from each other, but there are no secrets from the audience. You always know why Big Ant acts distant or aggressive towards his son, and oftentimes when it will occur, as well as the ways it will (fail to) resolve. Highpoints, such as when Big Ant quietly admires the craftsmanship of his son's Pegasus wings before rejecting them for confused reasons, unproductively blend together with facile ones, like a signposted scene of physical abuse. ‚ÄúIf I Go‚Äù exhibits frequently strong formal and writerly instincts that the lapses ‚Äî Dell and Nicholson's affected voiceover, the choice to chintzily animate Lil Ant's sketches, the bouts of flowery writing‚Äîfeel especially disruptive. Thompson-Hern√°ndez's discreet abstention from stereotypical depictions of poverty and gang life would be notable on its own, but that he de facto replaces them with visions of urban stableman who view horses like healers is a powerful substitution. Moreover, his decision to embrace the incompleteness of life as ‚ÄúIf I Go‚Äù reaches its conclusion instead of using tragedy to artificially juice the drama suggests a refreshingly mature artistic worldview, something that the Sundance Film Festival, not to mention the film industry as a whole, could stand to support. ‚ÄúIf I Go Will They Miss Me‚Äù premiered at the 2026 Sundance Film Festival. It is currently seeking U.S. distribution. Want to stay up to date on IndieWire's film reviews and critical thoughts? Subscribe here to our newly launched newsletter, In Review by David Ehrlich, in which our Chief Film Critic and Head Reviews Editor rounds up the best new reviews and streaming picks along with some exclusive musings ‚Äî all only available to subscribers. By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy. We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


OTHER

‚ÄòParanormal Activity' at Shakespeare Theatre Company is a horror hoot
Source: DC Theater Arts    Published: 2026-01-30 19:07:26

Yelps and screams abounded at the performance I saw. You should know that I am not the target audience for Paranormal Activity, a stage adaptation of the Paramount Pictures movie franchise running at Shakespeare Theatre Company through February 7. I am a wimp, a wuss, a weenie, with a time-tested talent for weaseling out of movie nights with even a whiff of public fright. But more so, I am a sucker for spectacle, and this Paranormal Activity ‚Äî which leans heavily on illusion and ambient creepiness instead of the ‚Äúfound-footage‚Äù format of its film iterations ‚Äî is a horror hoot. Playwright Levi Holloway, whose Grey House haunted Broadway in 2023, has cooked up an original story that finds newlyweds Lou (Cher √Ålvarez) and James (Travis A. Knight) settling into a life in London, where they've been placed in stately corporate housing. They decamped from Chicago, where Lou's mental health had deteriorated from an unshakable sense of dread, but even with new digs and medication, spooks emerge with a seemingly strong hunger for blood. Lou tries to keep the spirits at bay ‚Äî at one point enlisting a medium-turned-podcast-host Mrs. Cotgrave (Kate Fry), whose refrain is ‚ÄúPlaces aren't haunted, people are‚Äù ‚Äî while James attempts the same with his devout mother Carolanne (Shannon Cochran), who insists on visiting the couple from her home in Florida. Initially skeptical, James doesn't take long to accept that something is amiss. As the spirits take hold of their home, the couple is left to salvage their fracturing relationship as each learns who they really married. Typically, stage productions are built around texts, but when the task is to recreate an expected experience from existing intellectual property, in this case, the Paranormal Activity movie franchise, nimbleness is required, and it seems that Holloway's play was instead purpose-built to deliver that experience foremost. That's not a bad thing, though, and he impressively hits the necessary notes to create a story that is both believable and able to tee up the night's biggest tricks. Holloway veers away from referential pastiche by rooting the story firmly in today, and delightfully invokes everyday technology to remind us that even if we're not being haunted, we're still being watched; Alexa, Zoom, FaceTime, and even ‚Äútargeted ads‚Äù make appearances. In a genre known for tropes, he does an especially good job of developing Lou and James, and √Ålvarez and Knight are both giving truthful performances even as their surroundings become more extraordinary. Fry and Cochran also do their best with their characters, who are mostly devices, but Holloway's naturalism slips noticeably with puzzling, folksy lines like ‚ÄúYou both look like flapjacks left in a skillet overnight‚Äù that land with a thud. And not all of the various threads he pulls on throughout the two-hour play are tied up by the play's slapdash end, leaving some plot questions lingering and the moral of James and Lou's story muddy. It makes little difference, though. Originally directed by Felix Barrett and restaged here by Holloway, Paranormal Activity is relentless in building intoxicating anticipation from the first blaring sound cue. Even as the play cascades through a series of climaxes, one remains on tenterhooks, anxiously awaiting the moving of an object (Chris Fisher is illusions director and pulls out all the stops) or the roar of an alarm (sound design is by Gareth Fry) or a shadow on the wall (video/projections by Luke Halls) or a blackout (lighting by Anna Watson). Fly Davis' house set is big, expensive-looking, and ‚Äî I don't know how else to put it ‚Äî alive. Downstairs, a kitchen melts into a vestibule, then into a living room, in one continuous space with no walls, only furniture obstacles. Upstairs, Lou and James can finally find privacy from each other in a bedroom, bathroom, or nursery, but the same doors and walls that allow them to hide from each other may also be hiding the things they don't want to face. Try to stop your eye from darting around the space, asking yourself whether a spirit crossed a wall (did it?) or if something is about to move in the darkness (will it?). Across town at Studio Theatre, Octet, a chamber musical about ‚Äúdigital dependency,‚Äù has audiences locking away their devices to guarantee a ‚Äúphone-free experience.‚Äù Paranormal Activity demands something similar of its audience, though no pouch is required; it moves so quickly and promises so intently that, without saying so, its directive is clear: you'd better not look away for a second. Given the scale of the spectacle, it's not a tall order, but the results are thrilling nonetheless. Yelps and screams abounded at the performance I saw, which inadvertently helped this wimp/wuss/weenie (and others like me, I'm sure) remember that it's only a play. I expected to be surprised, but not in the way I ultimately was. At its best, theater is a kind of seance between the audience and the play, and even with its frozen-in-celluloid roots, Paranormal Activity facilitates that connection here with great success. There's a reason we return to Agatha Christie's murder mystery The Mousetrap and Noel Coward's supernatural comedy Blithe Spirit ‚Äî a tradition that Paranormal Activity, simultaneously playing in London's West End, now joins. Audiences don't need to scream, but they do want a reason to lean forward and listen. Even so, somehow jump scares feel good in a place like this. Running Time: Two hours and 10 minutes, including one intermission. Paranormal Activity plays through February 7, 2025, in the Shakespeare Theatre Company's Harman Hall, 610 F Street NW, Washington, DC. Tickets (starting at $43) can be purchased online, by calling the Box Office at 202-547-1122, or through TodayTix. The Asides program is online here. Paranormal ActivityBy Levi HollowayDirected by Felix BarrettRestaged by Levi HollowayIn co-production with Chicago Shakespeare Theater, Center Theatre Group, and American Conservatory Theatre CASTCher √Ålvarez, Travis A. Knight, Kate Fry, Shannon Cochran, Kira Cornell, Caron Buinis, Carikube Henricks, Michael Holding CREATIVEScenic & Costume Designer: Fly Davis, Lighting Designer: Anna Watson, Sound Designer: Gareth Fry, Video/Projections Designer: Luke Halls, Illusions Designer: Chris Fisher, Intimacy & Fight Coordinator: Chels Morgan, Dialect Coach: Susan Gosdick
